narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this class I developed skills that allowed me to analyze and have a different perspective on cultures unfamiliar to me. I gained confidence in my ability to engage with material and present it to the class in the form of presentation and discussion leading. I gained a new world perspective.

we learn about the stories of defectors who left north korea, missionaries who went into north korea, americans who crossed the DMZ into North Korea, and much more. these are the stories of many who have one thing in common: north korea
knowledge about north korea through memoirs and films, a more complex understanding of what north korean citizens and officials go through
I learned a lot about what the people of North Korea are going through.

Learned about North Korea in an academic setting for the first time. Read first-hand accounts of North Korean citizens and defectors, soldiers, and missionaries.  Learned a lot about the cultural and historical context of the region.

New insights about not only North Korea but the deep readings and memoirs made me humanize the citizens of North Korea. I was provided a new point of view on how I think about religion and what religion constitutes
Learned about the Kim family, North Korea's political relations, Juche ideology, and read many memoirs from North Korean escapees.
Learned about North Korea from the POV of actual North Korean people. Really refreshing given North Korea usually is only presented through a geopolitical lens.
Learned a lot about North Korea and the stories of those who defected.

I learned a lot about North Korea and what life is like there based on memoirs by defectors.  Through reading these memoirs I was able to get a more nuanced and unbiased portrayal of North Korea. I also learned a lot about the path that defectors take to escape North Korea, and the obstacles that they face on their journey. Also, I learned about the politics of North Korea and the history behind the establishment of the nation.
I learned about North Korea this year.
Understanding people and why they act the way they do no matter how terrible their actions are at face value

Read a wide range of memoirs about North Korea. For a country that has very minimal information about it, and the information we do receive from the media is heavily biased, this class allowed me to explore topics and histories I would have never otherwise come across.
I learned so much about North Korea and about the lives of people there, nearly from every echelon of society

I learned not only about the political history of North Korea but also about the personal experiences of North Koreans. Through reading the memoirs, I realized how important it is to dig deeper than just analysis of statistics.
History of North Korea and the structure of its societal system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of the course are that it is discussion based. Prof Kim allows each of us to lead a discussion and this helps us to engage in the course.
strengths: the class readings are very interesting, and the professor is helpful!

strengths: the readings and films selected were all very interesting, and the guest speakers were great
weaknesses: disorganized use of class time (split between lecture, guest speakers, individual presentations on random subjects, discussion leading on the hw), not much accountability for completing the material
great course
All strengths, no weaknesses

Lecture mixed with student presentations -- lecture given by Professor Kim was very engaging and interesting. Student presentations were also really interesting because most people actually cared about the class and put in effort.
Strengths include the lectures given by Hwansoo Kim, which were very engaging and informative.
Prof Kim is the major strength of this course. He is so caring and knowledgable. Really cares about his students.
I wish it had been the size it was meant to be! Prof Kim was too nice when letting so many people in.

Overall, I enjoyed the subject material and felt as though the course gave me a new perspective on North Korea and defector narratives. I did feel like, though, the class was mostly student presentation-centered and didn't engage in overarching themes as much as I hoped it would. I would love to see Professor Kim dedicate more time to a guided discussion on the readings that ties them to the week's theme and broader ideas in North Korean culture and identity.
This course is great! You learn so much and get a better perspective on the lives of North Korean defectors and life in North Korea. There are no weaknesses!

As much as I appreciated the interactiveness of letting the students give the class presentations, I really enjoyed it when Professor Kim would just lecture and share his thoughts. I thought that hearing from him was extremely valuable.
I think the structure can be changed.

Engaging, lots of memoirs, amazing professor. 
People were not really willing to speak up and ask questions. Sometimes I felt like people had preconceived notions still about certain faiths and also assumed everyone agreed with them on their respective views which isn't necessarily true. I wish we had access to the slides.

Hwansoos commitment to his students was perhaps the greatest strength of this course. That he opted to allow so many more students into the class than originally intended reflected his kindness and hesitance to exclude anyone who showed genuine interest. Particularly at the end of the course, when he was left to grade dozens of extra papers with no help from TFs (based on the comments I received, he truly did read them carefully!), he was willing to take on extra work to make sure every student received personal attention. 

There were two main areas of improvement for this course, in my view. The first is the number of people allowed to take it. Since the class as structured this semester included individual student presentations, allowing 60 or 70 people to take the course meant we all spent wayyyy too much time listening to four, five, or even six presentations per class. It ate up a lot of time I would much rather have spent listening to Hwansoo lecture. The course should either be restructured to accomodate a larger cohort of students or admit fewer people. Admitting dozens of students and then teaching it like a 15-person seminar was the worst of all options. 

The second opportunity for improvement regards the relevance of our readings and assignments. Although the premise of the course was a study of North Korean civic religion, the various memoirs we read spanned a variety of focuses, and few meditated extensively on the leadership cult. Similarly, student presentations spanned pretty much every topic imaginable, most of which had nothing to do with religion in North Korea. There was no requirement, either, that our final papers address the nominal thrust of the course. I think it would make a lot more sense either to broaden the idenitifed focus of the course and choose a new organizing principle or impose more discipline on the readings and assignments, because the status quo is a little unfocused.
I loved the book selection and the lectures! I don't have any critiques!
Strengths: content is super interesting and prof kim. was super engaging and brought a lot of speakers in

Strengths: the readings were super interesting, and the weekly discussion responses allowed students to engage more fully with the memoirs. It was also cool to have students lead each week's reading discussions. 

Weaknesses: I don't think the individual student presentations were super helpful, as they became a little repetitive and were difficult to engage with. I think if you got rid of these and kept only student-led book discussions, students might be more engaged throughout the class. I also enjoyed your lectures and preferred the lecture to book discussion format of class.
I loved the professor! I think the journal entries are helpful to keep up to date with the readings. And listening to the presentations/lectures were super interesting!

This course was extremely interesting and I was excited to hear from Professor Kim everyday in class. The material is simply very thought-provoking and I love how we looked at North Korea from a lens completely different to what we traditionally hear in the media. A weakness would be that we often did not actually hear from Professor Kim due to the multiple presentations that quickly backlogged and had to be completed by students.
Engaging and interesting

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! I learned so much and found all of the readings incredibly interesting. Gained a new perspective on the country and also just learned more about it historically.

I would certainly recommend this course to any student, because it allows for a new understanding and perspective. It actually teaches you to break prejudices and think about things differently from a human perspective.
yes, i would recommend to anyone who does not have a background in north korea; you will learn a lot!
yes, if one is willing to sincerely invest time into doing the readings/screenings. if not, the class feels a bit unstructured
Definitely, loved the course layout and the instructor and it was really cool to take a course focused on memoirs and personal testimony.

Yes -- if you want to learn more about North Korea, this will not only give you insight about the country but also change your perspective on how you approach your own life. I strongly encourage everyone to take this as you will not regret taking it.
Yes, I recommend any class taught by Professor Kim!
Yes, Professor Kim is excellent. So kind and interesting. Has a very unique and compelling point of view.
Yes, its a great class where you can learn a lot given most of the content is not common knowledge. Professor Kim is an amazing lecturer.
Yes! Super interesting and engaging, really cool readings
Yes, if you are interested in Korean history and identities I would recommend this course.
I would definitely recommend this course! Professor Kim is a great professor and goes out of his way to make the class more about learning rather than grades!
yes, one of my favourite classes! I actually enjoyed writing the final essay and it's insightful

If Hwansoo keeps a tight lid on the number of students he allows into the course, then you should count yourself lucky to be among them. He is a sparkling lecturer, attentive teacher, and interesting thinker. If the course is structured like a seminar but you have dozens of classmates, then maybe wait for a different semester.

Absolutely. Prof Kim is an absolute gem who really cares about his students. He provides so many out of class opportunities to engage in the material. From the mayor of Seoul to meeting a North Korean defector, this class is super special
Yes! an amazing course!

Yes! Professor Kim is a great lecturer and you learn a lot about North Korean society. You sort of have to be self-disciplined to remain engaged in the class, but the content is super interesting and Professor Kim is great.
Yes! Learned so much and great professor.
